member.name: T:MSSQLBI.Web.Style
member.summary: Represents the style for OlapControl web server control.

remarks.para: The Style class represents the style properties for the elements of the . You can control the horizontal alignment of the contents in the object to which the style is applied by setting the property. You can specify the text color and font of a object by setting the and properties, respectively.
The class also provides some static properties for easy creation of pre-defined styles.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.LevelType
member.summary: Defines the characteristics of the Level.
member.remarks: The LevelType could be used as a means to transmit formatting instructions to an application. For example, a level with a type of LevelType.TimeDays may indicate to an application that the members of the level should be expressed in text format (in other words, "Sunday", "Monday", "Tuesday", and so on). LevelType.Regular can be used to signify a level that does not require any special formatting.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl
member.summary: Olap Web Server control helps to query olap cubes and render the result to the client.

remarks.para: As you might already know, cubes are the main objects in online analytic processing (OLAP), a technology that provides fast access to data in a data warehouse. A cube is a set of data that is usually constructed from a subset of a data warehouse and is organized and summarized into a multidimensional structure defined by a set of dimensions and measures.

A cube provides an easy-to-use mechanism for querying data. Olap Web Server control helps to connect to an Analysis server and query the cubes on the server, over the web. Developers can then let end users issue a query on a cube by manipulating the control, which determine the contents of the query.
The Olap Web Server control also provides a rich user experience on the client side by leveraging the power of web browsers and DHTML behaviors.

member.name: M:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.ExecuteQuery(MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.MdxConnection,System.String,System.Boolean,MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.XmlaSoapClient)
member.summary: The ExecuteQuery method is used for sending action requests to a Microsoft XML for Analysis Provider server. This includes requests involving data transfer, such as retrieving or updating data on the server.
member.param: Specifies the connection to use for executing the query
Specifies the MDX query to execute
The flag specifies the format of the returned result set (Mulitdimensional | Tabular).
A object to be used for making soap requests to XML/A web service. The value can be a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
member.returns: XmlElement object which contains the result xml returned by the XML for Analysis Provider.
member.exception: The specified connection parameter is Empty.
The specified mdxQuery parameter is an empty string.
The specified mdxQuery parameter is null.

remarks.para:
The parameter and flag define the shape of the result set returned by this method.
The two result set format are Tabular and Multidimensional, as specified by the client through the parameter. OLAP data lends itself to the Multidimensional format (although the Tabular format can also be used) and OLE DB for Data Mining data uses the Tabular format.
Note: The Drillthrough queries only work with Tabular format.
The xmlaSoapClient parameter could be null (Nothing in Visual Basic) which means that the method will use default instance of for making soap requests to XML/A web service.

member.name: E:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.ResultCubeChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the state of the ResultCube changes between posts to the server.

remarks.para:
The ResultCubeChanged event is raised when the state of the ResultCube changes between posts to the server. This could be due to some user action like drill-down, drill-up, filtering, slicing of members. This could also happen when designer is being used to change the layout of the cube.
Note: An OlapControl must persist some values between posts to the server for this event to work correctly. Be sure that view state is enabled for this control.
This event is not fired when making changes to the ResultCube programmatically on the server side.

member.name: E:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.Drillthrough
member.summary: Occurs when a drill through action takes place on one of the data cells in the control.

remarks.para: Drill-through is an industry-standard term for reaching into the underlying fact table records for a cell or cells in an OLAP cube.

Drill-through enables a client application to access data from the tables that underlie the cube. Drill-through must be specifically enabled in the cube, and each partition of the cube may have different settings for drill-through.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.AllowDrillthrough
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether or not users can drill-through on cells.
member.value: true if drill-through should be allowed on the cells; otherwise, false. Default is false.

remarks.para:
The AllowDrillthrough property only determines whether the control should allow the end users to drillthrough on cells. Whether the drillthrough actually happens depends on cube's setting and also on the access permissions set on the olap cube.
Drillthrough is not supported for cells that have values based on expressions such as calculated member cells or ones that are associated with custom member formulas.

Drillthrough permissions are granted through membership in cube roles. The only end users who can drill through are those in cube roles that have been granted this ability. You can grant this ability in SQL Server Analysis Manager's Cube Role Manager or through programming with Decision Support Objects (DSO).

Apart from that in order to execute a DRILLTHROUGH statement on a cube, drillthrough must be enabled for that cube in the SQL Server Analysis Manager's Drillthrough Options dialog box. The property on the returns this setting.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.FixHeaders
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether or not to fix the headers when content scrolls.
member.value: true if the headers should remain fixed when the content scrolls; otherwise, false. Default is true.

remarks.para: When set to true, FixHeaders uses client side DHTML behaviors for the effect. So the actual implementation of this property is dependent on the capability of the client browser.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.ViewStyle
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates viewstyle for the control when rendered to the browser client..
member.value: One of the ClientView enumeration values.
member.exception: The specifed ViewStyle is not a valid ClientView enumeration value.

remarks.para:
The ViewStyle determines the extent to which end user can interact with the control user interface.
ClientView Description
ClientView.Static The user can only view the data.
ClientView.Dynamic The user is able to drill-up, drill-down, filter or slice the data.
ClientView.DynamicWithDesigner Apart from drill-up, drill-down, filter and slice features, users can use the runtime designer to change the layout and structure of the cube being shown.

para.note: When set to Dynamic or DynamicWithDesigner, the control uses client side DHTML element behaviors to provide rich interactive user experience. The actual working of this property is dependent on the capability of the client browser.

member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the control is automatically resized to display its entire contents.
member.value: true if the control automatically resizes based on the content being displayed; otherwise, false. Default is false.

para.note: If AutoResize is set to true, then SplitPositionTop property is ignored while displaying the slicer pane along with the grid. This could effect the positioning of other page elements beside the control.

member.summary: Gets or sets the caption to use for the Measures dimension.
member.value: The caption to user for the Measures dimension. The default is String.Empty.

para.note: The default String.Empty value for MeasuresCaption means that a browser-locale dependent display string is used for measure caption.

remarks.para: There can be scenarios where the olap cube has data in one language but the client locale could be different. User could set the MeasuresCaption property to a value depending on the language of the cube.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.MemberThreshold
member.summary: Gets or sets the threshold when retrieving a list of members.
member.value: The threshold value to be used when retrieving dimension members for the cube. The default value is 15.
member.exception: The specified MemberThreshold value is less than or equal to zero.

remarks.para: Use the MemberThreshold property to specify the maximum number of child members to retrieve for a given member in a dimension.

So for any given member, if the number of child members exceed the limit set by MemberThreshold then the member metadata is not retrieved. This reduces the amount of data being sent to the browser client. User could chose to forcibly retrieve the child members by drilling down or slicing on the given member.

Set this property at the design time or in the Page_Init method. The property is used while loading the state of the OlapControl and hence needs to be set before the control is actually loaded.
If the property is set on or after Page_Load then it only takes effect on next postback for the page.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.Web.Olap.OlapControl.ColumnHeaderStyles
member.summary: Gets a HeaderStyleCollection that represents the Styles used in the column headers.
member.value: A HeaderStyleCollection that represents the Styles used in the column headers.

remarks.para: The objects in the ColumnHeaderStyles collection are applied to the dimensions added to the of the in order of their position. It means that first dimension added to the uses the first object from the ColumnHeaderStyles collection, the second dimension uses the second object, and so on. If there are not enough objects in the ColumnHeaderStyles, then the first one is used again.

para.note: If the ColumnHeaderStyles doesn't contain even single HeaderStyle object, i.e., the collection is empty, then the control uses the default in-built HeaderStyle style for the row headers.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.Measure
member.summary: Defines a Measure for Cube object.

remarks.para: In a cube, a measure is a set of values that are based on a column in the cube's fact-table and are usually numeric. In addition, measures are the central values of a cube that are analyzed. That is, measures are the numeric data of primary interest to the end users browsing a cube.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.BaseDimension
member.summary: Defines a BaseDimension object which defines the structure of the cube.

remarks.para: Dimensions are structural attributes of cube. They are organized hierarchies of categories and levels that describe data in the fact table. These categories and levels describe similar sets of members upon which the user wants to base an analysis.

Each cube dimension can contain a hierarchy of levels to specify the categorical breakdown available to end users. For example, the Store_Location dimension includes the level hierarchy: Continent, Country, State_Province, City, Store_Number. Each level in a dimension is of finer granularity than its parent. For example, continents contain countries or regions, and states or provinces contain cities. Similarly, the hierarchy of the Fiscal_Year dimension includes the levels Year, Quarter, Month, and Day.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.Dimension
member.summary: Defines a Dimension object which defines the structure of the Result Cube.

remarks.para: Dimensions are structural attributes of cube. They are organized hierarchies of categories and levels that describe data in the fact table. These categories and levels describe similar sets of members upon which the user wants to base an analysis.

Each cube dimension can contain a hierarchy of levels to specify the categorical breakdown available to end users. For example, the Store_Location dimension includes the level hierarchy: Continent, Country, State_Province, City, Store_Number. Each level in a dimension is of finer granularity than its parent. For example, continents contain countries or regions, and states or provinces contain cities. Similarly, the hierarchy of the Fiscal_Year dimension includes the levels Year, Quarter, Month, and Day.

Dimension levels are a powerful data modeling tool because they allow end users to ask questions at a high level and then expand a dimension hierarchy to reveal more detail. For example, an end user starts by asking to see Item_Cost values of products for the past three fiscal years. The end user may notice that 1998 Item_Cost values are higher than those in other years. Expanding the Fiscal_Year dimension to the Month level, the end user sees that Item_Cost values were especially high in the months January and August. The end user may then explore levels of the Store_Location dimension to see if a particular region contributed significantly to the high Item_Cost values, or may expand into the Product_Line dimension to see if Item_Cost values were high for a particular product group or product. This type of exploration, known as drilldown, is common in client applications.

The is used to create an output cube based on the cube containing the source data. This could be done by adding dimensions on to one of the axes on the result cube. Users could further access individual members of any particular dimension added to the result cube and perform drilling or slicing on them.
The control then generates a query based on the output cube being designed by user, runs this query on the source cube and renders the result data to the client.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.BaseLevel
member.summary: Defines a BaseLevel object as an element of the dimension hierarchy.

remarks.para: Level is an element of a dimension hierarchy. Levels describe the hierarchy from the highest (most summarized) level to the lowest (most detailed) level of data.
Levels exist only within dimensions.

Levels are defined within a dimension to specify the contents and structure of the dimension's hierarchy. That is, the level definitions determine the members that are included in the hierarchy and their positions relative to one another within the hierarchy.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.DrillthruCell
member.summary: Provides access to the drill-through query to access data from tables that underlie the cube.

remarks.para: Drill-through is an industry-standard term for reaching into the underlying fact table records for a cell or cells in an OLAP cube.

Drill-through enables a client application to access data from the tables that underlie the cube. Drill-through must be specifically enabled in the cube, and each partition of the cube may have different settings for drill-through.

member.name: M:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.DrillthruCell.#ctor(System.String,MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Mdx.Tuple,MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Mdx.Tuple,MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Mdx.Tuple)

member.name: M:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.DrillthruCell.GetMdx
member.summary: Return an array of MDX drill-through queries for the DrillthruCell represented by the object.
member.returns: An array of strings, each string representing one MDX drill-through query.
member.remarks: The SlicerAxisTuple property of the DrillthruCell might consists of one or more calculated members. Since calculated members are not supported in drill-thruough query, so this method returns an array of mdx queries, one for each unique combination of all the members in the SlicerAxisTuple.

member.remarks: The FirstRowSet value defines a positive integer that specifies the relative partition from which the drill-through rows will be obtained. There is no way to limit the number of overall rows returned, except by combining this with the MaxRows option.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.DataSource
member.summary: Defines a DataSource for XML/A service.

remarks.para: A data source contains the information necessary to access source data for an object such as a cube. Although the term data source is sometimes used to refer to the source data itself, in this topic it refers to the data source object, which is used by to establish connections to the source data.
A data source specifies an OLE DB provider and settings for the other properties in the connection string used to access the source data. The property set varies according to the selected provider.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.Catalog
member.summary: Defines a Catalog containing the olap cubes.

remarks.para: A catalog is a container for related cubes and the objects they share. These objects include data sources, and shared dimensions. If these objects are to be shared among multiple cubes, the objects and cubes must be within the same catalog (database).

Catalogs (databases) are immediately subordinate to the Analysis server in the object hierarchy. Thus, after an Analysis server is installed, databases are the first objects to be created. For more information, look for help on Analysis Services in MSDN/SQL Server documentation.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.Cube
member.summary: Specifies the olap cube.

remarks.para: Cubes are the main objects in online analytic processing (OLAP), a technology that provides fast access to data in a data warehouse. A cube is a set of data that is usually constructed from a subset of a data warehouse and is organized and summarized into a multidimensional structure defined by a set of dimensions and measures.

A cube is defined by the measures and dimensions that it contains. For example, a cube for sales analysis includes the measures Item_Sale_Price and Item_Cost and the dimensions Store_Location, Product_Line, and Fiscal_Year. This cube enables end users to separate Item_Sale_Price and Item_Cost into various categories by Store_Location, Product_Line, and Fiscal_Year.

Each cube dimension can contain a hierarchy of levels to specify the categorical breakdown available to end users. For example, the Store_Location dimension includes the level hierarchy: Continent, Country, State_Province, City, Store_Number. Each level in a dimension is of finer granularity than its parent. For example, continents contain countries or regions, and states or provinces contain cities. Similarly, the hierarchy of the Fiscal_Year dimension includes the levels Year, Quarter, Month, and Day.
For more information about dimensions, levels, and measures, see Dimensions, Levels, and Measures.

member.name: T:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube
member.summary: Defines a result cube object. This class helps design the result set layout in terms of multidimensional cube.

remarks.para: Cubes are the main objects in online analytic processing (OLAP), a technology that provides fast access to data in a data warehouse. A cube is defined by the measures and dimensions that it contains.

Each cube dimension can contain a hierarchy of levels to specify the categorical breakdown available to end users. For example, the Store_Location dimension includes the level hierarchy: Continent, Country, State_Province, City, Store_Number. Each level in a dimension is of finer granularity than its parent. For example, continents contain countries or regions, and states or provinces contain cities. Similarly, the hierarchy of the Fiscal_Year dimension includes the levels Year, Quarter, Month, and Day.

Dimension levels are a powerful data modeling tool because they allow end users to ask questions at a high level and then expand a dimension hierarchy to reveal more detail. For example, an end user starts by asking to see Item_Cost values of products for the past three fiscal years. The end user may notice that 1998 Item_Cost values are higher than those in other years. Expanding the Fiscal_Year dimension to the Month level, the end user sees that Item_Cost values were especially high in the months January and August. The end user may then explore levels of the Store_Location dimension to see if a particular region contributed significantly to the high Item_Cost values, or may expand into the Product_Line dimension to see if Item_Cost values were high for a particular product group or product. This type of exploration, known as drilldown, is common in client applications.

The is used to create an output cube based on the cube containing the source data. This could be done by adding dimensions on to one of the axes on the result cube. Users could further access individual members of any particular dimension added to the result cube and perform drilling or slicing on them.
The control then generates a query based on the output cube being designed by user, runs this query on the source cube and renders the result data to the client.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.RowAxis
member.summary: Gets an AxisDimensionCollection that represents the Row Axis of the query result.
member.value: An AxisDimensionCollection that represents the row axis of the query result.

remarks.para: The RowAxis property specifies the y-axis of the . The user could add dimensions from the into the row axis. Users could further access individual members of any particular dimension added to the result cube and perform drilling or slicing on them.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.ColumnAxis
member.summary: Gets an AxisDimensionCollection that represent the Column Axis of the query result.
member.value: An AxisDimensionCollection that represent the column axis of the query result.

remarks.para: The ColumnAxis property specifies the x-axis of the . The user could add dimensions from the into the column axis. Users could further access individual members of any particular dimension added to the result cube and perform drilling or slicing on them.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.SlicerAxis
member.summary: Gets a AxisDimensionCollection that represent the Slicer Axis of the query result.
member.value: An AxisDimensionCollection that represent the slicer axis of the query result.
member.remarks: Any dimensions that don't appear in the ColumnAxis or RowAxis will nevertheless still have some member involved in the query. If you don't specifiy any such dimensions on the Slicer Axis, then the database will assume some reasonable defaults.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.Measures
member.summary: Gets a ResultMeasuresCollection that represent the collection of measures that are to be part of the query result.
member.value: A ResultMeasuresCollection that represent the collection of measures that are to be part of the query result.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.MeasuresOnRows
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that determines whether the measures lie on the row axis.
member.value: true if measures are placed on row axis; otherwise, false. The default is false.
member.remarks: This property takes effect only when the associated measure dimension has not been added to any of the Axes on the result cube.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.ShowEmptyRows
member.summary: Determines whether empty cells on the RowAxis should be excluded from the result dataset.
member.value: true if empty cells on the RowAxis should be included in the result dataset; otherwise, false. The default is false.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.ShowEmptyColumns
member.summary: Determines whether empty cells on the ColumnAxis should be excluded from the result dataset.
member.value: trueif empty cells on the ColumnAxis should be included in the result dataset; otherwise, false. The default is false.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.DimensionClearState
member.summary: Gets or sets the clearing state when a dimension is moved between the different axes.
member.value: One of the DimensionState values. The default value is DimensionState.ClearNever.

remarks.para:
The DimensionClearState determines what happens to a Dimension's state when it is moved from one of the result cube axis to another.
DimensionClearState Description
DimensionState.ClearAlways Always clear the dimension state when moved between the axes.
DimensionState.ClearIfSliceArea Clear the dimension state only if moved to or from the Slicer Axis.
DimensionState.ClearNever Never clear the dimension state.

member.exception: The specified value is not a valid DimensionState enumeration value.

member.name: P:MSSQLBI.XmlAnalysis.Data.ResultCube.MultiSelectSlicer
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the slicer support multiple selected items.
member.value: true if the slicer supports multiple selected items; otherwise, false. The default value is false.

remarks.para: The MultiSelectSlicer property also determines the behaviour of the slicer picklist UI element (rendered to the client as part of control).

para.note: This property doesn't applies to a measure Dimension on the slicer axis. The measure dimension never allows multiple selection of member items.
